sections.heading: A Game Changer: Functional Nano/Micromaterials for Smart
sections.text:
Rechargeable Batteries
Jaegeon Ryu, Woo-Jin Song, Sangyeop Lee, Sungho Choi, and Soojin Park*
The imperative to electrify the transport sector in the past few decades has put millions of electric vehicles on the road worldwide with an extended mile range from critical technological breakthroughs in developing the rechargeable energy storage systems, which also covers electronic devices and smart grid applications. However, the available energy density of prevailing systems in the market (i.e., batteries) is reaching its boundaries due to the limited choice of electrochemical reactions that necessarily depend on the thermodynamics and kinetics of the components (e.g., cathode, anode, electrolyte, separator, and current collectors). Reaching the high energy density of batteries exploits new redox chemistry such as sensitive metal anodes, insulating and highly dissolving sulfur cathodes, etc., thus requiring novel designs of various multiscale functional materials to address the corresponding issues. Here, the recent achievements on the designs of smart functional materials for emerging problems in the whole range of systems are discussed: i) interfacial control/kinetic regulation of Li–S battery; ii) self-healing-driven structural stability in the electrode and electrolyte; iii) ion-sieving functional membranes for selective scavenging capability; and iv) functional materials to ensure battery safety.

yielded have improved performances in reality (doubled specific energy density >300 W h kg−1, extended service life (>10 years) of systems, increased driving mile range (>300 miles) of electric vehicles (EVs), etc.), the current state-of-the-art batteries or supercapacitors are still lagging behind to afford the rapidly expanding energy storage markets.[3] Thus, low cost, smaller, lighter, more versatile, and higher energy density of systems is urgently required along with the recently raised issue of decreasing the charging time of batteries.[4] Another option meeting these rigorous criteria includes metal– air or metal–sulfur systems (metals: Li,[5] Na,[6] Mg,[7] Zn,[8] and Al[9]) using O2 or sulfur as the positive electrodes, respectively, though, of which realized energy density fell far short of their theoretical expectations owing to the mostly lack of suitable electrolyte regulation even in the high-impact literature and their related research fields have a long way to go.[10]
Alternatively, redox-flow systems operate with a flow of liquid (or semiliquid) redox species initially stored in tanks necessarily combined with functional membranes and predominate in the sustainable grid-scale energy storage due to abundant salts and cost effectiveness but suffer from heavy accompanying hardware.[11]
The beyond the limit of the energy density of prevailing devices always begins with replacing a certain component inside the traditional LIBs that primarily comes down to the exploration of host materials for the charge (lithium ion) and charge-transporting media as described above. By means of advanced characterization techniques as well as theoretical calculations, in situ and operando monitoring of the materials and interfaces is now available under the operating conditions.[12] We moved a step closer to the deep understanding of the electrode materials and relevant properties, which enables so-called novel designs to boost the overall performances of EESSs as chronologically arranged with the specifications ranked in innumerable review articles.[13] However, apart from the particular indexes derived from the charge storage materials (typically anodes and cathodes) including cycle life, round-trip efficiency, operating voltages of systems, and so on, a comprehensive insight becomes more significant into which characteristic functions or smart materials in different scales have been performing a pivotal role in realizing the present EESSs, rechargeable batteries in particular.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rechargeable energy storage systems have led a technological renaissance in various electronic applications, addressing the global energy challenges originated from ever-growing demands for renewable energy and the advent of electrified transportations, since the successful launching of prototypical lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) to the consumer market in the early 1990s.[1] Among the multiple electrochemical energy storage systems (EESSs) that can convert reversibly electric energy into chemical energy through thousands of electrochemical redox couples,[2] batteries and supercapacitors are the most representative systems widely used in the modern society by complementing each other in terms of their insufficient energy and power density. Although there have been extensive efforts to develop the advanced version of such devices and some breakthroughs

Tracking the path of charge-carrier ions during the electrochemical process, we are quickly aware of how many subreactions or phase changes they encounter across the transporting media (solid-state, solid–liquid, gas–solid reactions). This indicates that an intact migration of single charge-carrier ion requires supporting materials designed for a specific purpose, also referred to as functional materials, stage-by-stage.[14] In a microscopic viewpoint, such functional materials improve the efficiency and reliability of the energy storage according to consumers’ needs, for example; with the increasing demands on high energy density of EESSs beyond the conventional LIBs, the systems proposed above use new redox chemistry between host materials and charge-carrier ions, undergo different deformation patterns in their intermediate states, and eventually call for new types of functional materials that have never been tried (e.g., redox mediators (RMs) in post-Li batteries or aqueous/nonaqueous deformable electrode systems).[14,15] Further, other cell components, such as separators, packaging materials, and electrolytes rather than the host materials (integrated with binders), can be classified as the functional materials in a macroscopic viewpoint, which allows the normal operation of systems. Micro- or nanostructural assembly of cell components, meanwhile, mimicking the biological systems that are analogous to electrochemical reactions in EESSs but never achieved from the artificial systems, can provide new perspectives on the design of functional materials in certain cases.[16] Along with these lines, the intricate structure of EESSs necessitates a variety of emerging multifunctional materials and followed smart functions for developing the versatile devices in the near future and, therefore, it is highly required for the understanding of prime but relatively unconcerned functions based on the multiscale materials.
The bottom line featured in this review article lies in investigating the functional materials that have been undervalued in the past few years while emerging as one of the overriding factors with different scales and purposes designed for sustainability, integrity, efficiency, and safety of rechargeable batteries. Section 2 first focuses on the functional nanomaterials related to the regulation of interfacial properties of systems that passivate the surface of sensitive battery materials or enhance the transport of charge-carrier ions. Section 3 presents how the smart function of self-healing can integrate the entire structure of systems at the level of electroactive materials (host materials), electrodes (binders), and electrolytes. Section 4 provides recent strategies to address the secondary challenges of metal dissolutions from transition metal-based cathode materials and the resulting deterioration of counter electrode by using the functional scavenging materials in nano/microscales (additives/membranes). Further, the selective ion-permeable functional membranes are introduced to increase the efficiency of systems. Section 5 highlights the recent progress in the smart functional materials that can resolve the safety issues with appropriate actions for the thermal runaway process. Section 6 spreads the multitude of functional materials which we have not touched in this review and proposes the potentially far-reaching materials for postlithium chemistries.

Afterward, he joined the Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH) as a postdoctoral research associate. His research

Afterward, he joined the Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH) as a postdoctoral research associate. His research interests have focused on the development

After he completed his postdoctoral fellowship at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, he became a professor in the School of Energy and Chemical Engineering at UNIST in 2009. Since 2018,

sections.heading: 2. Interfacial Nanoscale Regime
sections.text:
A repetitive flow of charge-carrier ions drives classical batteries across the electrolyte (metal salt dissolved in organic solvents) and a separator between two host electrodes (Figure 1a). Over the past decades, the battery component has evolved

again and accordingly requires an understanding of the basic property of the components and functioning mechanism in the devices.[17] Of paramount importance is their interfaces where the dynamic redox reactions occur in reality which affect battery behaviors such as lifespan, charge transport efficiency, selfdischarge properties, etc.[18] The most crucial upheaval appears at the interface between the host materials and the electrolyte (solid–liquid), which entails side reactions at potentials outside the thermodynamically stable window of the electrolyte. At the low reductive potentials (<0.8 V vs Li/Li+), most organic solvents are reduced to form a thick (<20 nm) passivation layer (referred to solid electrolyte interphase, SEI) at the anode/ electrolyte boundary,[19] while the opposite electrode has a relatively thin (<1 nm) solid permeable interphase (SPI) or cathode electrolyte interphases (CEI) layer with their different chemical compositions.[20] Importantly, these interface layers provide ionic channels and electron-insulating property which inhibit direct contact between the host materials and the liquid electrolytes to avoid parasitic reactions.[21] Comprehensive studies establish a theory on a formation mechanism of such interface layers,[22] how to render it stable by functional additives[23] or electrolyte modulations[24] and surface treatments based on model intercalation compounds[25] as well as promising high energy materials of Si anode[26] and nickel/lithium-rich oxide cathodes.[27] However, pursuing another option for high energy density systems requires additional in-depth insight into the design of functional materials for interfacial stability.
Li–S batteries, in this perspective, are a stimulating system consisting of two problematic subjects; sensitive lithium metal anode and the highly dissolving sulfur cathode (Figure 1b). Since the sulfur cathodes are already charged, the operation of the cell starts with discharge in which the oxidation of the lithium metal provides lithium ions/electrons and sulfur cathodes are reduced into lithium sulfide by accepting the charges. The backward reactions will occur during the charging process that gives high theoretical gravimetric energy density of 2510 W h kg−1 despite its low average cell voltage of 2.15 V (vs Li/Li+).[28] Although the system operation seems straightforward at first, there are plenty of hurdles that complicate the charge storage mechanisms in both anode and cathode. For the lithium metal anode, dendritic deposition of lithium metal in a hostless form of materials during charge causes safety and cyclability issues of the electrodes.[29] For the sulfur cathode,
the electronically insulating sulfur (≈10−30 S cm−1) and lithium (di)sulfides (Li2S, Li2S2) formed during the cycling, resulting in loss of electrochemical contact between the sulfur particles.[30] Also, dissolution of lithium polysulfides (Li2Sx, x > 2) in the typical electrolytes leads to shuttling behavior that disables the interfaces of electrodes with recurrent liquid–solid transitions significantly increasing the cell impedance.[31] Which functional materials become key enablers to address the two major challenges in different scales at the interfaces of such system?

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Stable Film Formers
sections.text:
The high reactivity of lithium metal yields the uncontrollable formation of dendritic and irregular plating structure along with severe side reactions at nanoscales. The interface layer between the sensitive lithium metal and electrolytes and its component/structure have a huge impact on the behavior of dendrite nucleation and growth.[32] Thus, the primary consideration of the lithium metal anodes has been interfacial stability by introducing a stable, robust, and ion-conducting film.[33] The decomposed products of conventional electrolytes (SEI) are not capable of providing sufficient ion flux through the layers while its uneven structure failed to preclude the possibility of electron conduction which incurs an aggressive formation of a dendrite with a poor mechanical property.[34] The use of electrolyte additives (or different electrolyte formulation[33f,g,35]) would be a cost-effective and efficient approach to physically and chemically modify the interfacial layers and to regulate the lithium metal deposits.[36] In the early days of researches, several classic additives[37–39] previously used for the anode host materials were investigated along with an intensive focus on lithium nitrate additive (LiNO3);[40] for example, fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC)-containing electrolytes formed a LiF-rich, dense, and stable SEI layers on compact lithium metal deposits in most cases, while the electrolyte solution added with vinylene carbonate (VC) and ethylene sulfite (ES) created resistive layers and lithium deposits.[36]
Unlike the additives of which structures are analogous to those of cyclic or linear organic solvents and decomposed to constitute the SEI layers, various deposition-guiding materials

The uniformly distributed nanosized seeds over the Cu substrate enabled the guided growth of lithium metal in the highly compact and dendrite-free structure as demonstrated with Li-rich composite alloys.[44] However, this guiding ability is only valid at the limited current density up to 0.5 mA cm−2 far below the recent requirement for charging conditions, and the additives no longer support the guided depositions with an increased current density. This low threshold implies that successive lithium deposits on the top of seed-guided layers are out of control at a fast ion flux and suggests the need for regulating agents of charge-carrier ions which can draw them near the substrate and make a relatively uniform ion flux. Otherwise, such nanosized seeds should be placed inside the ion-permeable carbon shells to limit the spatial distribution.[45]
Interestingly, diamond nanoparticles (≈500 nm) with negatively charged surfaces electrostatically draw the lithium ions and the ion clouds over the diamonds are transported to the Cu substrate under the electric field during the charge (Figure 2b).[46] Afterward, the nanodiamond (ND) nucleates the growth of lithium deposits as a heterogeneous seed with its crystal size less than that of the diamonds (<350 nm) compared to the lithium deposits in the neat electrolyte (>1.2 µm). The guided codeposition of lithium metal and ND does not alter the interfacial resistance during the subsequent cycles and a reversible stripping-off was observed to maintain the additive concentration as low as 0.82 mg mL−1. The self-depositing but guiding materials from the electrolytes regulate the plating structure, thus increasing the operation time of battery without a short circuit. The remarkably high hardness of nanodiamonds deposited in the first layer or its stacked structure contributes to physical suppression of dendrite formation, although it turns out later.[47] Additionally, the most recent work proposed functional rules for designing the guiding materials, particularly doped carbons.[48] From the elaborate theoretical calculations and supporting experimental evidences, the electronegativity, the strength of local dipoles, and fast charge transfer (i.e., >0.9 e−) of dopants (either single or codopants) critically impacted deposition of lithium metals, thus revealing that O (oxygen) and O/B (boron) doping strategies have the highest lithiophilicity (good lithium affinity) toward the homogeneous depositions.
Artificially designed protecting interface of reactive metal anodes suppresses the dendrite formation once it balances the ion and electron conductions even from the classical viewpoints.[49] The desired structure of SEI layers involves the outer porous organic layers which enable the fast diffusion of ions and inner dense inorganic layers of an electronically insulating property. The latter should have a sufficiently evolved thickness to prevent electron tunneling phenomenon while avoiding the attack from the trace water or internal stress generation.
However, some mixed conducting interface films with an inner electronic channel render a stable cycling performance of lithium metal anode as contradicted with the requirements of SEI layers.[49b,50] Archer and co-workers recently introduced a simple ion-exchange reaction to introduce the electroactive Sn-rich layers consisting of Sn nanoparticles distributed over the reaction product layers (Figure 2c).[51] The morphology of the overlayer looks like a typical Zintl phase, thus featuring a rather glassy but solid-like structure. This Sn-bearing artificial layers (thickness of 500 nm–2 µm) lower the interfacial resistance and boost the fast charge transfer kinetics through the impedance analysis. The deposited metal and alloy layers of hybrid anodes appear as if the extensively covered seed layers render the ion flow uniform with additional support from decomposed organic species during the film formation as meeting the above requirement.
Very recently, graphite fluoride–lithium fluoride (GF–LiF)protected lithium metal anodes were adopted for air-stable and dendrite-free electrode preparations in either liquid or solidstate electrolyte systems (Figure 2d).[52] The favorable reaction between lithium metal and graphite fluoride generates LiF inner layer beneath the hydrophobic GF outer layers. Compared with the pitted surface and stiff SEI layers of pristine lithium metal, which serve as a potential site of dendrite formation and dead lithium metal deposits, the GF–LiF layers are more elastic and have a reduced modulus, giving flexibility and resilience to the SEI layers during the repeated cycles. Even after exposed to air more than 24 h, GF–LiF–Li anode showed outstanding reversibility for extended cycles, which have practical feasibility at a high current density. Instead, formulating the electrolytes in a solid state could modulate the ionic flux at the solid–solid interface (with a poor ionic conductivity less than 10−4 S cm−1) to naturally and physically suppress the dendritic growth of lithium metal. The newly developed 3D gel polymer electrolyte (3D-GPE) guarantees high mechanical strength and high ionic conductivity due to the large accommodating ability for electrolyte solution and solvated lithium ions (Figure 2e).[53] This one-pot ring-opening polymerization process minimizes the inefficiency from the by-products of the thermal initiators and high flexibility of electrolyte films induces the stable formation of SEI layers. Yet, gel polymer-based electrolytes are not suitable to apply the currently investigated high voltage cathodes and comparable design concept both against the lithium metal anode and high voltage cathodes are an urgent matter of developing a high energy density battery. Figure 2f shows a heterogeneous multilayered solid electrolyte (HMSE) structure of Li1.4 (Al0.4Ge1.6(PO4)3 electrolyte passivated by two different polymer layers.[54] The oxidation-resistant poly(acrylonitrile) (PAN) layer faces the cathode side, while the lithium metal makes a contact with reduction-resistant polyethylene glycol diacrylate layer to realize a stable high voltage battery. By extension, SBAtemplated SE, fluorinated polymer-based SE, etc., have been proposed to address the dendritic formation issue of lithium metal anode at the interface to date.

Conventional polyolefin-based separators (e.g., polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP), and multilayered structures) cannot sufficiently serve as a physical barrier to prevent the dendrite piercing, which call for mechanically strong polymer-based separators with higher Young’s modulus than that of conventional ones (≈15–150 MPa)[55] as one of the promising alternatives. Kotov and co-workers utilized the layerby-layer assembled composite membranes of aramid fibers and ion-transporting poly(ethylene oxide), of which elastic modulus increased by more than 500 times, and both thermal and electrochemical stability were significantly improved.[56] Similarly, nanoporous poly(p-phenylene benzobisoxazole) membranes with Young’s modulus of 20 GPa could effectively suppress the formation of dendrites.[57] Contrary to the previous understanding of separator designs that Young’s modulus of polymer separators should be higher than the threshold value from the theoretical calculations,[58] the recent publication found that rubbery membrane without any porosity inhibited the dendrite growth with the modulus of ≈0.4 MPa due to the matched modulus to that of mossy lithium deposits.[59]
The other way of the separators to have an influence on the lithium metal anodes has been focused on fabricating the composite membranes incorporated with additional top layers having an ion-transporting property. By extension of simple wetting-accelerator of organic material,[60] Zhang and co-workers cast oxide nanoparticles widely used in the solidstate batteries on the top of the routine separator that redistributes the charge-carrier ions infiltrated through the separator in a regulated manner.[61] The penetrated lithium-ion flux has an extremely low deviation across the confined spaces between the lithium metal and the separator to be ideal for dendrite suppression. Otherwise, the metallic surface modifications of the commercial PE separator through the costeffective magnetron sputtering method increase the affinity of lithium metal depositions on the separators, thus eventually modulating the morphology of deposits on the lithium metal sides.[62] These metallic layers also contribute to the thermal stability of the batteries. In recent days, the separators serve as more than the physical barrier of the anode and cathode but instead performed a vital role of modulating the lithium-ion flux or mechanically buffering the dendrite growth to make the lithium metal anodes stable over the prolonged cycles, which can be easily accessible and straightforward compared with the direct engineering on the lithium metal anodes. The other important functionalities required for the advanced batteries will be discussed in the later section.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Artificial Caging Matrixes
sections.text:
The current collectors in the conventional batteries have a fundamental role of passing the uniform current (electrons in particular) to the other cell components such as the host materials or conductive carbons through the external circuit while keeping an electrostatically charged state in either direction. The current flow over the 2D planar structure limits the charge distribution across the thick electrode at a commercial
level, thus giving a restriction on the fast charging ability of the battery. Besides, the nucleation of lithium metal deposits on the current collectors might strongly depend on its interfacial nature, structure, morphology, and length of charge transport, which call for developing the 3D current collectors with an increased electroactive surface area to enhance the lithium-ion flux to the entire substrate and accommodate a large volume of lithium metal deposits.
Given good electrochemical stability at a low potential range of 0.01–2 V (vs Li/Li+), Cu,[63] Ni,[64] and stainless steel[65] fit the anode current collector for metal depositions prepared by the metal plating on hard template or assembly of metal nano/ microstructure or transformation of the planar structure into the 3D porous structure in general. Simply, the surface modification of Cu foils with Cu(OH)2 fibers and subsequent reduction reaction built the 3D skeleton structure of submicron lush and bent Cu fibers.[66] These plentiful protuberant tips on the fibers contribute to the homogeneous charge distribution only with nanosized lithium lump grown because of the extremely higher electroactive surface area even compared with that of metal foam. Guo and co-workers reported a channellike structure of Cu substrates followed by a similar design of microcompartmented anode arrays from Yang and co-workers (Figure 3a).[67] The effects of vertically aligned microchannels on the deposition behavior of lithium metal are thoroughly studied in terms of different pore radius, depth, and spacing. The even formation of lithium deposits on the upper surface and inside the channels is related to a large current density observed in the curved surface of channels in a good agreement of the lightning rod theory. The optimized geometric parameters caged the lithium deposits inside the microchannels to minimize the deposits located between the pores and improved the cycling efficiency, thus suggesting a guideline of the porous designs.
Contrary to the lithiophobicity (poor lithium affinity) of typical metal substrates, carbon in a wide variety of allotropes, sp2-hybridized materials, shows high electronic conductivity through the delocalized π clouds and deformable structures, which can be potentially used as a current collector showing an increased lithiophilicity depending on the functional groups, doping characters, defect structures, and configurations.[68] The partially or fully graphitized carbon materials actively react with lithium ions in the intercalation forms of the battery-type and adsorption forms of the capacitor-type energy storages, which might cause unusual Coulombic inefficiency of the batteries. Therefore, the very limited choice of carbon substrate has been used for the current collectors of lithium metal anodes, such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and carbon nanofibers. The carbon substantially reduces the mass fraction of current collectors (≈10% in the total mass of cell) and increases the specific energy density of systems.
Analogous to the metal foams but much lighter graphene foams ensure a strong binding with infused lithium metal accelerated by the surface decorating agents of metal oxides (Figure 3b).[69] Since the nanoflake structure of metal oxides renders the surface nature of graphene much lithiophilic and offers open spaces to reduce the volume changes, the interface becomes intimately contacted with the deposits for its enhanced wettability toward the metallic lithium, stabilized and

Along with the decorated graphene frameworks, flat and smooth morphology of the deposits were observed during the cycles in absence of trace of lithium dendrite by virtue of flexibility and large cavity of the current collectors. In addition, modulating the electronic conductivity and prestored lithium ions by compositing the graphene with Ti3C2 MXene diminishes the dendrite formation of lithium metal deposits (Figure 3c).[70] As the current collectors, the MXene scaffold affords both high ionic and electronic conductivity that is adequate for homogeneous nucleation and growth of the deposits. When large amounts of capacities are stored in this architecture (>5 mA h cm−2), the interconnected voids and numerous macropores facilitate sustainability of lithium metal anodes.
Another host type for the lithium metal depositions is illustrated in Figure 3d.[71] The overlithiation of mesoporous AlF3 produces the nanocomposite structure (LAFN) consisting of Al4Li9, LiF and lithium metal. Due to the intrinsically lithiophilic AlF3 powder, molten lithium metals fully permeate into the frameworks and the resulting products are readily pelletized, while still maintaining the interior pores and showing an improved wettability toward the liquid electrolyte. The initially infused lithium metal into the ionically and electronically conductive matrix is well caged by mechanically stable LiF buffers and accordingly showed a near-zero volume change upon the repeated deposition and stripping process. By means of LiF-protected skeleton, interfacial resistances of LAFN during the first cycle is 200 times less than that of pristine lithium metal anode and this unique structure unprecedently endures a high current of 20 mA cm−2. Although it is apparent that the proposed frameworks fulfill the most requirements for the lithium metal anode and are large-capacity reservoir of the lithium metal like the recent work of Al2O3 skeleton with Li–Al–O layer,[72] the presented thicknesses of host current collectors are so thick (≈760 µm) that the volumetric energy density of a full cell will be far behind the those of other thin 3D current collectors.

The caging matrixes for lithium metal deposition are not necessarily metallic or carbon materials. A 3D crosslinked poly(ethylene imine) sponge, proposed by Wang and co-workers can be used for the host structure as shown in Figure 3e.[73] This 3D polymeric porous sponge (PPS) has a strong ion affinity, leading to a higher localized concentration inside the structure and a formation of the electric double layer, which distinctively features an electrokinetic pumping to promote the lithium ion transport. With an impressively high porosity of 87%, the sponge host accommodates 74.6 wt% of lithium deposits due to its high interconnectivity. As a result, the lithium deposits are stored inside the sponge host with compensating the initial porous structure up to the 6 mA h cm−2 and the deposition stably occurred even at −10 °C. The self-concentrating and pumping effect contributed to resolving the dendrite issue of lithium metal anode and simultaneously achieved a promising electrochemical performance at the near-commercialization conditions (low negative-to-positive (N/P) ratio).

sections.heading: 2.2. Sulfur Cathodes
sections.text: At the beginning of Li–S batteries, introducing conductive encapsulating cages (e.g., metals[74] or carbons[75]) for the sulfur cathode showed the way addressing the critical obstacles as which mainly arise from the dissolution of host materials and low electronic conductivity. In terms of practical manner, however, such strategies cannot be attainable owing to the low utilization amounts of sulfur cathodes and thus, realizing the Li–S systems call for more feasible, effective, and straightforward strategies in recent years. The alternative approaches are based on interfacial functional materials named “kinetic accelerator” which reduce charge overpotentials by boosting either charge transfer or ion transport. Basically, there are two types of kinetic accelerators depending on where they are positioned during the operation of the battery; cathode-interface accelerator and electrolyte regulators. Both accelerators smoothen the charge transfer and improve the redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides related reactions.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Kinetic Accelerators at Cathode Interfaces
sections.text:
Kinetic accelerators at cathodes interfaces can be defined as host materials with “polar” or “sulfiphilic (good sulfur affinity)” properties for efficient kinetic mediation. Polarity enhances charge transport which leads to the fast transition of lithium polysulfides to Li2S/Li2S2, while sulfiphilicity facilitates reasonable desorption and surface diffusion of lithium polysulfides to block shuttle phenomenon. There have been many candidates suggested for the kinetic accelerators at cathodes interfaces; elemental metals which have widely used as catalysts for a variety of chemical and electrochemical reactions take the initiative in modulating the interfacial kinetics. Intrinsic metallic conductivity and unique d-band structure of metals are beneficial to the effective transition of lithium polysulfides to Li2S/Li2S2. Zhang and co-workers designed porous platinum (Pt) nanostructure decorated on the sulfur microparticles for stabilizing the sulfur cathode and suppressing the shuttle
effect.[76] The designed cathode showed a volumetric capacity of 520 mA h cm−3 and an extended cycle life of the battery with a capacity retention of 85% after 80 cycles at 0.1 C (167.5 mA g−1). In addition, transition metals have been investigated for substituting a novel metal-based design in the Li–S systems. Dong and co-workers suggested a metal–organic framework (MOF)derived sulfur host structure consisting of cobalt (Co) and nitrogen-doped graphitic carbon (Co–N-GC).[77] The presented ideal conductive matrix and trapped polysulfide in the structure catalyzed electrochemical reactions at the interface, thus enabling the normal operation of Li–S systems for 500 cycles at 1 C and Coulombic efficiency as high as 100% even at the high sulfur loading (70 wt%) conditions.
Low-cost materials including transition metal compounds and organic-based kinetic accelerators at sulfur cathode interfaces are proposed as shown in Figure 4. The transition metal compounds feature adjustable polarity which supports strong interactions with lithium polysulfides. Also, their unsaturated sites on the surface contribute to the function of kinetic mediators. Among different types of transition metal compounds including hydroxide,[78] oxide,[79] nitrides,[80] sulfides,[81] and MXene[82] with its different roles, it is important to choose appropriate materials for the Li–S system. Sun and co-workers suggested the paramontroseite catalyst for efficient polysulfide conversion reaction (Figure 4a).[83] With the uniform VO2 nanoparticles grown on parallel nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube (NCNT) arrays, 3D freestanding hierarchical structure was successfully designed as a sulfur host. Inside the host, the paramontroseite nanoparticles enhance the charge transfer and ion diffusion which enables fast redox kinetics. In addition, catalyzing the conversion reaction of soluble lithium polysulfides to insoluble polythionate complexes and shortchain ones could effectively suppress the polysulfide shuttling phenomena. The designated cathodes achieved a discharge capacity nearly close to the theoretical values with stable electrochemical cycling which corresponds to a capacity retention of 67% for 500 cycles at 2.0 C even at high sulfur loading conditions. Lightweight metallic MgB2 as polysulfide redox promotor, meanwhile, was reported by Nazar and co-workers as shown in Figure 4b.[84] Although it cannot be classified as the transition metal compounds, the polar and ultralight metallic boride, MgB2, has the exclusively strong boding sites of B and Mg surfaces to the anions, greatly enhancing interfacial charge transfer in comparison with that of oxide/sulfide-based compounds. The MgB2 composite allowed efficient utilization of sulfur and stable cycling of compact electrodes due to the ultralight weight of kinetic accelerators (6.18 mA h cm−2 over 100 cycles at 0.2 C).
Developing the weight-efficient metal-free kinetic accelerators has received much attention including redox-active organic molecule/carbon composites or organosulfur.[85] A key element for designing proper metal-free kinetic accelerators lies in engineering the specific active sites and understanding the interresponse with the lithium polysulfides. Very recently, Chen and co-workers demonstrated a straightforward method by using anthraquinone (AQ) molecules which could catalyze the redox reactions and be readily incorporated with graphitic carbons via π–π stacking for improving electric conductivity (Figure 4c).[86] The carbonyls groups of AQ are able to confine the polysulfides

The designed S-anthraquinone-reduced graphene oxide (rGO) composites (S-AQ-GO) showed negligible decay of capacities for 300 cycles with a high sulfur loading condition (≈73 wt%). Importantly, the theoretical simulation results demonstrated increased binding energy of AQ molecules on the conductive carbons and different types of polysulfides. Meanwhile, the synthesis of sulfur-rich polymers with high conductivity made a breakthrough for the significantly improved battery cycle life consisting of sulfur cathodes and lithium metal anode. The chemically stable materials can be obtained from the copolymerization with different linkers, suppressing the lithium polysulfides dissolution due to the strong covalent bonds between carbon framework and sulfur. Park and co-workers synthesized high amounts of sulfur-linked polymers via inverse vulcanization that could increase utilization amounts of active sulfur and facilitate redox kinetics as illustrated in Figure 4d.[87] Due to the homogeneous distribution of sulfur in the conductive matrix to boost the lithium transport and effective chemical entrapping of polysulfides on the keto groups, synthesized poly(STABQ) showed good rate capability result of discharge capacity of 833 mA h g−1 at 10 C and 74% of capacity retention at 500 cycles at 1.0 C with average Coulombic efficiency of over 97.2%.

Because of inherently ionic/electronic insulating properties of electrode materials (sulfur and lithium sulfide), the charge storage reactions only occurred by generating the soluble lithium polysulfides intermediates diffused to the conductive surface and then going through various reactions. Zhang and co-workers introduced lithium polysulfide catholytes that enable a universal self-healing in Li–S batteries as extrinsic healing agents to allow stable electrodes consisting of micron-sized sulfur cathodes for hundreds of cycling. As illustrated in Figure 5b,[89] lithium polysulfides catholytes inhibit the initial spatial inhomogeneity of lithium polysulfides distribution derived from electrochemically produced lithium polysulfides from the sulfur cathodes. A uniform initial distribution of lithium polysulfides in the working cell leads to a homogeneous deposition and smooth reoxidization of discharge products. Besides, uniform deposition at initial state ensures that large amounts of generated polysulfides during further cycles solubilize deactivated solid products. Moreover, the model experiment with the I2 as another additive was introduced for facile oxidation of the bulk Li2S to highly colloidal sulfur particles (I2 + Li2S = 2LiI + S) which enhance further dissolving of Li2S into polysulfides.
Given that the electron transfer also critically determines the reversible charge storage in the Li–S battery, the regulators should have a redox reaction of their own redox couples, leading to an electrochemical activation. The regulators with a clear redox pair which occurred at above the potential for the Li2S can chemically oxidize Li2S across the interface with the electrolyte and then electrochemically reoxidized that the current collectors. Thus, multistage charging voltages appear when such kinetic accelerator additives are added. For reducing the voltage hysteresis during each cycle of charging and discharging while increasing the Coulombic efficiency, the slightly high redox potential of additives is desirable than the equilibrium potential of Li2S (2.15 V vs Li/Li+). Very recently, Bao and co-workers introduced the redox chemistry of quinone-based accelerators to enable improved redox chemistry of sulfur cathodes without lithium polysulfide catholyte (Figure 5c).[90] With the anthra-9,10-quinone (AQT), direct electrochemical oxidation plateau was observed at 2.25 V versus Li/Li+, and electrochemical reduction of Li2Sx occurred. This result implies that the AQT has been chemically converted into AQT− followed by chemical oxidation of Li2S into Li2Sx. The AQT as an electrolyte regulator for kinetic acceleration lowered polarization (low average charge potential) with high Coulombic efficiency (87.5% after 500 cycles). Also, the capacity of 850 mA h gsulfur−1 was retained after 500 cycles at 1 C, whereas the capacity of the bare cell decayed dramatically within only 10 cycles. Until now, we introduced the multiscale functional materials to address the critical issues derived from polysulfide dissolution as well as poor electronic conduction in the advanced Li-ion battery. Also, there have been lots of valuable approaches that are proposed in the viewpoint of interlayer modification[91] and functional separator.[92] However, the presented bunch of followed-up works do not come down to an obvious consensus and understanding of multistate transition during the redox reaction of sulfur cathodes as well as how effectively regulate such systems
are obscured by the raised issues from the other components in Li–S battery. Thus, realizing this complicated system would be up to master the fundamental problems inside the systems and to recognize the required functions and design principles based on the above discussion.

sections.heading: 3. Self-Healing-Driven Structural Integrity
sections.text:
The batteries necessarily undergo a physical deformation originated from the electrochemical reactions[93] or should be deformable to power the stretchable and flexible devices.[94] The former is closely related to the structural changes of the host materials or entire electrode upon the insertion/extraction of charge-carrier ions which depend on the amount and types of charge storage. The latter mostly refers to the electrolyte concerns when the system itself makes use of different cell architectures like an aqueous battery[95] and solid-state battery.[96] Unlike device-level engineering, an initial formulation of battery components determines a shelf life of systems without any chance to further mend the interior defective or disintegrated structure when it enters a failure mode (Figure 6a). Even welldesigned functional materials inside the battery degrade rapidly due to accidental damages or accumulated fatigue during the battery operation. Thus, self-healing materials would evidently offer a great opportunity for such systems of poorly accessible areas, which exhibit biomimetic smart functions to selfrepair the damages in either autonomic or nonautonomic ways depending on the need for external triggers (e.g., heat, light, electricity, or mechanical load).[97] The terms “extrinsic” and “intrinsic” can be also used to describe another property of each self-healing process.[98] Extrinsic self-healing materials themselves are not capable of repairing the damaged sites; rather it contains external healing agents hidden inside the vascular or capsules which later break to release the healing agent to restore the structure into the initial state or enable a normal operation (Figure 6b).[99] Intrinsic self-healing materials, on the other hand, provide reliability and durability of systems without the external healing agents (Figure 6c). Instead, the intrinsic self-healing can be achieved through the inherently reversible bond reconnection between the polymer molecules, predominantly, covalent (Diels–Alder reactions[100]) and intermolecular interactions (hydrogen bond,[101] dipole–dipole,[102] and van der Waals interactions[103]).
Based on the same underlying concepts to self-heal the damages (or cracks), the generation of the mobile phase is indispensable for the operation of self-healing that physically brings the edges of the damaged sites closer by the directed mass transport to the area or local mending reaction from the chemical reactions above. Regarding the battery operation, a continuous flow of electrons and charge-carrier ions complete intact energy storage through the external circuit and electrolyte to the host materials, respectively, i.e., achieving the electrode integration to secure the electron pathway and supplying the uniform ion flux under the severe deformation conditions are still challenging. First, we deal with how to integrate the electrode structure that continuously varies due to the large structural change of the host materials during insertion/extraction of ions by using the self-healing polymeric binders or self-healable host

Since the proposed novel structures are not feasible toward the commercialization of Si anodes until the present, the design of polymeric binders integrating the bulk Si particles holds great potential for the entire electrode integration in small quantities.
According to thorough investigations on design roadmap of binders for Si anodes (or high-volume-change anodes), strong supramolecular interactions of polymer binders are desirable to recover the dissociated bonds with high reversibility (referred to self-healing effect), while stiff nature of covalent bonds (or crosslinking between polymers) will be eventually ruptured and cannot be recovered during the prolonged cycles.[112,113] As the first attempt to realize the self-healing polymer (SHP) binder for Si anodes, Bao and co-workers synthesized ureabased amorphous SHP designed for Si microparticle anode which has a viscous fluidic behavior due to low glass transition temperature (Tg) below 0 °C to readily rearrange the polymer chain and to envelope the mechanically fractured sites.[114] This dynamic interaction from the hydrogen-bonding improved the structural integrity of the electrode, thus boosting the lithium storage performances. A different self-healing effect from the ion–dipole interactions was also verified using Si nanoparticle (SiNP) anode.[113] A more advanced version of SHP involves the polyethylene glycol (PEG of low molecular weight = <20 000 g mol−1) groups incorporated into the similar urea-based polymers, improving the ionic conduction of polymer network (Figure 6d).[115] By adjusting the crystallinity of polymer from the molecular weight and semicrystalline regions, amorphous nature of SHP associated with chain rearrangement was further mechanically enhanced which endures large volume change of Si anodes with the self-healing ability maintained. The optimized amounts of PEG render the Si electrode ionically conductive inferred from the reduced charge transfer resistance as well as bulk resistance. Homogeneous SHP layers over the electrode continuously mend the fracture points, retaining an intimate contact with Si particles which significantly suppress the pulverization of microparticles and improve the electrochemical performances.
Considering the complicated industrial process of electrode preparation, Wang and co-workers developed in situ formed water-soluble SHP in a form of poly(acrylic acid)-poly(2hydroxyethyl acrylate-co-dopamine methacrylate) (denoted PAA-P(HEA-co-DMA)) as shown in Figure 6e.[116] Highly
cohesive PAA chains form a rigid polymer network backbone covalently bonded to the Si particles. Then, the thermal condensation reactions between PAA and HEA/DMA reduce the rigidity of the network by introducing elastic moieties and abundant hydrogen bonding in the local structure that makes a stress-resilient polymer architecture. This rigid–soft modulated polymer binder effectively buffers the large volume change of Si microparticles (0.5–3 µm) with extremely high areal capacity loading of 3–9 mA h cm−2, thus ensuring the long-term stability of electrode (≈100% of capacity retention after 470 cycles at 1 A g−1) and remarkable rate capabilities (1855 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1). Dynamic recovery of fractured electrode interface during repeated expansion/contraction of host materials inevitably calls for self-healing property of polymer binders. Featuring the rigid structure to a certain extent typically from the covalently bonded network could additionally integrate the entire electrode components, while the design of well-balanced polymers suited for the commercialization of Si anodes still needs intensive research based on the above closeto-market cases.
Liquid metal (LM), a eutectic alloy of metals with a low melting temperature (Tm) near to or below the room temperature (<30 °C),[117] offers an alternative for high-capacity anodes benefited from its fluidic and resulting self-healing nature.[118] The LM electrode (Bi[119] or Sb-Sn[120]) studied previously should be heated to maintain the liquid state far beyond the temperature (>500 °C) for normal operation of batteries (<60 °C) in the molten salt electrolyte, thus posing the efficiency loss, sealing issues, and being out of considerations for future technologies. Therefore, various LM candidates showing a liquid phase regime at room temperature have been extensively investigated; gallium (Ga) draws much attention due to its relatively low Tg (29.8 °C) and large stoichiometric lithium storage property (Li2Ga alloy), yet the electrochemical evaluations were carried out at above 35 °C.[118] However, an early demonstration of Ga anodes was formulated as the thin film without the carbon conductive agent and polymeric binders which could not retain the intimate contact with the current collectors and showed a rapid capacity fading, although the microcracks on the electrodes were self-healed through the solid–liquid transformation.[121]
With the dispersion method of LM into the nanoparticles developed, Chen and co-workers stabilized the Ga–Sn liquid metal alloy (Tg ≈ 20 °C) in the rGO-CNT matrix, thereby preventing the escape of LM nanoparticles during charge– discharge cycles and extending the cycle life of battery up to 4000 cycles with no obvious capacity decay (Figure 6f).[122] Importantly, smooth and glittering electrode surface became rough and less glittering during the lithiation because of large volume expansion from Li–Ga alloy formation and its liquid– solid transition. Upon the subsequent delithiation, the surface recovered to the initial crack-free morphology owing to the self-healing property of LM itself but featured complex preparation steps and high production cost. In this context, Yu and co-workers prepared Ga–In eutectic alloys through a simple thermal alloying reaction at 250 °C for enough times, of which melting temperature is as low as 15 °C and electrochemical activities toward both Li/Na were verified (Figure 6g).[123] In parallel with the disadvantages of typical high-capacity host materials, bulk LM suffers from the sluggish diffusions of

Accordingly, reducing the diffusion length of charge carrier ions inside the alloy structure (i.e., nanostructuring of LM) could mitigate such structural instability and self-healing capability of nanosized LMs was significantly enhanced for both Li/Na case. Although their charge storage behaviors differ in the amounts of charge stored in the unit structure, size of ions, and kinetic energy during charging, the fully charged (delithiated) LM nanoparticles return to the liquid state and readily mend any deformed structures and make the electrode long lasting and fast chargeable along with high diffusion coefficient compared with other representative alloying-based anodes. It is obvious that LM anodes could deliver high capacity from the alloying/ dealloying reactions and its deformability dynamically closes the fractured sites up, but continuously changing the structure of LM cannot stabilize the interfacial layers which will rather impede the healing process, in absence of self-healing property of the layers. Further, self-healing ability of LMs is limited to a single particle of LM due to such layer (i.e., SEI), that is, the particles hardly form an interconnected structure even with this unique property. However, the fluidic nature of LM anodes is still promising for designing the high-capacity host materials, ultimately high energy density batteries.

sections.heading: 3.2. Self-Healable Electrolytes and Conductors
sections.text:
In the systematic view of energy storage systems, continuous ion flow from the electrolytes and electron transport from the current collector should be maintained even during the harsh operating conditions. For the future technology, polymer electrolytes, mostly fabricated by dissolving the different polymers into the conventional liquid electrolytes, are alternatively addressing the raised issues of the liquid electrolytes due to their inherent thermal stability and inhibited leakage of organic solvents. Nevertheless, PEs feature disadvantages such as sluggish ionic diffusion (10−6−10−8 S cm−1), poor interfacial stability and vulnerability to breakdown during deformation.[124] Inspired by spontaneous recovery property upon mechanical damage, assorted SHPs have been recently designed to overcome the above-mentioned issues and thus we will introduce various types of energy storage systems incorporated with self-healing properties for the electrolytes and current collectors (or conductors) as illustrated in Figure 7. By extension of Section 2, self-healing polymer electrolytes could effectively suppress the lithium dendrite formation in the lithium metal batteries suggested by Xue and co-workers (Figure 7a).[125] Multifunctional polymer electrolyte was fabricated by using a ureidopyrimidinone (UPy) with a monomer and poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (PEGMA). The quadrupole hydrogen bonding makes PE self-healable by reconstructing the damaged interfaces under ambient conditions without any external stimuli and highly stretchable more than 2000%. Because of the strong interaction between the hydrogen bonded crosslinking network and the electrodes, uniform distribution of Li ions over the lithium metal anode prevented a severe
growth of lithium dendrite and achieved a highly reversible electrochemical reaction. Further, cut and healed polymer electrolytes retained almost initial discharge capacity of cathodes (≈155 mA h g−1), suggesting that self-healing polymer electrolytes greatly contributes to continuous ionic flow.
The gel-type or solid polymer electrolytes with self-healing nature requires the addition of ceramic filers such as oxide particles mostly used in the solid-state batteries for high ionic conductivity. Liu and co-workers prepared a freestanding composite polymer electrolyte (CPE) membrane of which thickness is just 25 µm consisting of home-made garnet-type solid particles (Gadoped Li7La3Zr2O12 denoted as LLZGO) and fatty acid-based SHP after soaking in a slight amount of the conventional liquid electrolyte as shown in Figure 7b.[126] This hybrid membrane has intimate contact with lithium metal anodes due to the modulated viscoelasticity and self-healing capability that delocalizes and evenly distributes the lithium-ion flux even over the artificial protrusion of deposition nuclei to eliminate “hot spots” of potential dendritic growth compared with traditional polyolefinbased porous separators. Homogeneously dispersed LLZGO NPs in the self-healable polymer matrix significantly lowered interfacial charge transport resistance while negating large out-of-plane strain induced by deposited lithium metals. Thus, CPE-involved symmetric lithium metal batteries showed low hysteresis without sharp nucleation overpotentials and endured a high current density of 20 mA cm−2 for 1500 cycles. Although small amounts of liquid electrolytes were incorporated in this CPE, it still might cause safety concerns of flammability and leakages which hinder further use in forthcoming applications.
Very recently, stretchable electronics have been considered as next-generation technology for the various fields of applications such as sensors,[127] wearable devices,[128] and implantable devices[128b] that should be compatible with the human body and highly deformable. Conventional electrolytes, based on flammable and toxic organic electrolytes, that might cause a potential explosion during repeated mechanical deformation processes, are not undesirable for the stretchable electronic devices of which power sources need to be deformable as well. Therefore, aqueous electrolyte-based rechargeable energy storage systems including supercapacitors,[129] lithium aqueous batteries[94a,c] and zinc-based batteries[130] have been proposed as a safe and sustainable power source for stretchable electronics. Also, the electrode itself along with the electrolyte should be durable for the proper electron transport as demonstrated from all selfhealable lithium aqueous battery system by Pan and co-workers (Figure 7c).[131] In their system, both electrodes and electrolyte can self-repair simultaneously after mechanical damage. Owing to the dynamic borate ester bonding of electrodes and electrolyte, mechanical properties and lithium storage performances were quickly restored even during the multiple cut-offs. Also, it can be tailored into complicated patterns without significant deterioration in electrochemical properties.
For the reliable stretchable electronics to be developed, integration of energy storage systems with the devices is indispensable but less concerned only with a few demonstrations suggested. Figure 7d shows the representative work for the use of transistor by Haick and co-workers. A field-effect transistor (FET) was fabricated with all self-healable device components by a transfer printing method.[132] Self-healing and stretchable FET consisted

sections.heading: 4.1. Scavenging Material Designs for LIBs
sections.text:
The cathode is a critical component of the LIBs that determines the overall capacity (Ah) and operating voltage (V) of the cell, consequently related to energy density (Wh kg−1 or Wh L−1) of batteries. Among several cathode materials, Mn-based cathode materials, for instance, spinel LiMn2O4 (LMO), LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2, and LiMnO2 are envisioned to be promising candidates to achieve the high energy density LIBs because of their beneficial properties including high thermal stability, high rate capability, low toxicity, and natural abundance compared with conventional Co-based materials.[27a,138] However, the wide use of Mn-based cathode materials was hindered by the severe Mn-ion dissolution issues accelerated in high voltage, high temperature, high specific surface area, and acidic conditions.[139] Dissolved Mn cations from the cathode materials into the electrolyte cause rapid degradation of batteries[140] as follows: dissolved Mn cations migrate to the negative electrode and contaminate the SEI layer on the anode surface and continuous active material consumption with a significant increase in electrode impedance along with collapse of cathode crystal structure.[133c]
To address above parasitic reactions from Mn cation dissolution, multiple strategies were reported including cathode surface coating,[141] anode surface coating,[142] and transition metal doping on active materials.[133b,143] Although the aforementioned approaches were effective to suppress dissolution issues and deposition processes on the anode, trade-off relation still remains unsolved between the battery stability derived from the inhibition of Mn cation dissolution and required electrochemical performances (e.g., ion transfer efficiency and energy density). In this respect, Halalay and co-workers reported polymeric crown ether coated polyolefin separators that can selectively trap the Mn cations (referred to as “Mn cation scavenger”).[144] Compared with the baseline cell, less than half of dissolved Mn was deposited on the graphite anode surface with the proposed separator in LMO-graphite full cell after cycling. Interestingly, the mass analysis revealed that 6 to 15 times more Mn cations were trapped in the polymeric macrocycle coated separator (12–15 µg cm−2) than in the baseline polyolefin separator (1–2 µg cm−2) to show a feasibility to suppress Mn cation deposition, whereas the high cost of crown
ether-based materials hindered the practical use in LIBs. Alternatively, Banerjee et al. developed Mn cation trapping separators using poly (vinylidene fluoride–hexafluoropropylene) (PVdF–HFP) copolymer and a low-cost commercial resin composed of iminodiacetic acid disodium salt groups as chelating fillers.[145] The chelating agent filled separator showed rather improved capacity retention of 67% at high temperature (55 °C) in similar LMO-graphite configuration, compared with 47% from the untreated separator. Such suppressed Mn depositions on the counter electrode were further corroborated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement in which confirms lowered interfacial film and charge transfer resistance of the proposed separator than that from the plain separator.
Meanwhile, Aurbach and co-workers proposed the separator combining PVdF–HFP matrix with Mn chelating tetrasodium edetate (Na4EDTA) using the phase-inversion method.[146] Figure 8a shows the chelating mechanism of Na4EDTA agent that traps Mn cations by anionic interactions and electron donating nitrogen atoms. The constructed LMO-graphite full cells with the Mn scavenging separator retained 125% more capacity than with plain separator after cycling at 55 °C, which is ascribed to effective Mn cation trapping of the fabricated separator. Furthermore, as illustrated in Figure 8b,c, the increase of both high-frequency resistance and mediumfrequency resistance was significantly suppressed with the Mn chelating separator, of which resulting performance enhancements were attributed to the reduced amounts of Mn deposits on the anode surface. Although the proposed scavengers for Mn cations enabled normal operation of battery at severe operating conditions of high temperature, demonstrated cycle life of batteries was insufficient to drive the forthcoming applications with only attention to the mechanical property of separators in recent years. Instead, alleviating internal acidic condition could inhibit the Mn dissolution from the cathode because the acidity of the electrolyte strongly stimulates the destruction of the cathode. The MnO bonding of the cathode materials is vulnerable to attack from acidic species such as hydrofluoric acid (HF) and easily broken, thus leading to extraction of Mn cations from the cathode material structure and loss of usable energy sources.[147] In addition to impairing cathode materials, HF leaches SEI layer of the anode which protects the anode materials from additional electrochemical reactions with the electrolyte.[148] Consequently, the exposed anode surface leads to the decomposition of the electrolyte by providing electron pathways and accelerates the degradation of batteries. These phenomena are the major factor of compromising the battery performance, at especially over critical temperature (≈60 °C).[149] In general, residual water contamination of electrolyte results in hydrolysis of a lithium salt (in particular, LiPF6 is the most widely used lithium salt in conventional LIBs due to an optimum balance between ionic conductivity, chemical stability, and other additional properties).[150] Then, the lithium salt (i.e., LiPF6) reacts with a trace amount of H2O, generating detrimental HF molecules as shown in Equation (1).

Another functional electrolyte additive reported by Han et al. is tris(trimethylsilyl) phosphite (TMSP) that can form a highly uniform and stable protective layer on the cathode surface through the chemical reactions with HF molecules as shown in Figure 8e.[153] X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra after formation cycle demonstrated that the use of TMSP additive lowered the amount of undesirable reaction byproducts of LiF, which is a product of Li-ion and the SEI layer component with HF. The protective layer formed on the cathode surface could facilitate Li-ion transport corroborated by alternating current (AC) impedance spectra, showing that the electrolyte with TMSP exhibited significantly lower interfacial resistance compared with that from the baseline electrolyte. Besides the ensured facile ion transfer, the surface layer derived from the additive acted as a barrier that prevented transition metal dissolution of cathode materials, thus improving the cycle life of a battery up to 77.1% in comparison of baseline electrolyte system of 55.9% after galvanostatic 100 cycles. Recently, Xu et al. introduced TMSP and 1,3-propanediol cyclic sulfate (PCS) additives in high voltage LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 (LNMO) cathode battery system.[154] The electrolyte with binary additives delivered large reversible capacity at both room temperature (10.8% for bare electrolyte and 79.5% for binary functional additives after 500 cycles) and 50 °C (75.5% for bare electrolyte and 88.1% for binary functional additives after 100 cycles). Furthermore, EIS measurement results showed that interfacial resistance of the cell with binary functional additives was noticeably lower than baseline electrolyte system. These beneficial results are attributed to the synergetic effect of TMSP and PCS additives where TMSP worked functionally to trap the HF species in the electrolyte, while PCS decomposed preferentially and forms stable and ion conductive CEI layer on the positive electrode surface which also protected the electrode from the HF attack.
Recent progress on functional material designs for preventing parasitic reactions in LIBs is discussed in this section. Even though developing scavenging materials for LIBs is highly
desirable to drive improved battery performances given that such designed materials can address the Mn cation dissolution and/or HF attack, reversibility of the scavengers has not been studied to date. For developing sustainable devices, batteries should operate for more than thousands of cycles, which implies that the above introduced functional materials also need to be sustainable enough to continuously offer the intended use for the consumer. Thus, reversibility of such scavenging capability for long-term duration still required further elaborate and innovative designs from the molecular level based on the deep understanding of necessary functions inside batteries.

sections.heading: 4.2. Functional Membrane Designs for Li–S Battery Systems
sections.text:
The separator membranes, in the rechargeable battery system, fundamentally serve as the liquid electrolyte reservoir to provide the ion-conducting pathway while preventing physical contact of the cathode and the anode. Rational design of separator membrane with basic functions can yield the development of full-fledged rechargeable systems. Recently, however, with limited strategies for electrode material modifications, functional separator designs that alternatively mitigate degradation of battery performance are required for Li–S battery systems. As mentioned previously, long-chain polysulfide species (Li2Sx, 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) favorably dissolve in liquid electrolytes and lead to polysulfide shuttling effect where the polysulfides readily diffuse from cathode to anode.[155] The migrated polysulfides react with the Li anode and then are reduced to form insulating Li2S and Li2S2 which cause depletion of active materials, low Coulombic efficiency, self-discharge, and deteriorated cycle retention.[156] Despite previously demonstrated strategies to alleviate polysulfide shuttling including cathode modification and anode surface coating, they still suffer from additional drawbacks such as an increase in surface resistance and decay in energy density caused by the reduction of active materials.[157] Thus, multitalented separator membranes that can selectively capture the polysulfide species, while sieving Li-ions have been proposed based on carbon-based materials,[156a,158] metal– organic framework,[159] and modified polymer membranes.[160]
Although MOF structure has a tunable porosity and adjustable chemical properties suited for a promising polysulfide shuttling inhibitor,[161] highly brittle mechanical properties of MOF poses a critical constraint that hinders the efficient fabrication of MOF-based separator membrane for the battery system. Recently, Zhou and co-workers proposed the GO modified MOF-based functional separator for Li–S battery system.[162] It is noteworthy that mechanically robust GO enabled facile production of separator membranes incorporated with MOF (MOF@GO), of which 9 A° sized micropores effectively block the lithium polysulfide while allowing the Li-ion migration as illustrated in Figure 9a. To investigate the improved stability of cells, galvanostatic cycling performances of Li–S battery system with MOF@GO and bare GO separator were measured, respectively (Figure 9b). The cell with MOF@GO separator delivered a high discharge capacity of 855 mA h g−1 after 1500 cycles which is the fairly enhanced performance compared with what obtained from bare GO separator attributed to the efficient polysulfide blocking function of the MOF@GO separator. sections.heading: 5. Battery Safety
sections.text: Without any doubt, LIBs have become the first choice for various electronics from portable devices to large scale devices due to their high energy density and good cycling performance, as introduced at the beginning of this review. Despite these advantages, safety concerns of LIBs are predominant constraints to achieve reliable grid-scale energy storage and transportation applications (e.g., EVs, electrified airplane) powered by the electrochemical energy storage medium.[165] Indeed, several hazardous incidents of LIBs were recently reported; for example, in 2016, a Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphone had a representative explosion accident of battery and the company recalled all the distributed products (estimated to 5.3 billion dollars).[166] In addition to this accident, there have been countless accidents caused by the battery in our daily life. To address the safety concern of LIBs in both academic society and industry, tremendous efforts have been devoted to designing functional materials and a manufacturing process. In this section, we will briefly discuss a thermal runaway process that is major phenomena of battery safety issues and then afford an overview of the latest progress in advanced material designs for preventing the thermal runaway through thermal response polymer, flame retardant additives, nonflammable materials, and modification of cathode materials.

sections.heading: 5.1. Thermal Runaway Process
sections.text:
One of the most battery-related incidents of catastrophic failure is “thermal runaway” arising from mechanical damage,
electrical overcharging, and thermal abuse.[167] Thus, it is important to understand the thermal runaway process to establish a material design for safer batteries. Figure 10 briefly summarizes three different stages of triggered thermal runaway by the temperature rise of batteries from overheating process (e.g., overcharging and short circuit from internal and external defects).[168] First, an ion-conducting SEI on the anode decomposes at ≈70 °C. After the breakdown of the SEI layer, the organic electrolytes react with the electrodes and release flammable hydrocarbon gases in a form of ethane, methane, etc. (stage 1). At the battery temperature of over 130 °C, conventional polyolefin separator membranes such as PE, PP, and their blends, i.e., PE-PP start to melt, which cause an internal short circuit (stage 2). When the temperature further increases (>180 °C), the positive electrode materials such as LiCoO2 (layered structure) and LiMnO2 (spinel structure) decompose and release excessive oxygen gas (stage 3). Eventually, the batteries give great risk to catch fire and lead to the eventual explosion of the battery, imperiling the life and safety of consumers. The complicated thermal runaway process consisting of various chain reactions originates from the decomposition of the battery component in the current use—five key components of the anode, cathode, current collector, separator membrane, and organic liquid electrolyte (Figure 11). Among these components, the separator membrane and organic liquid electrolyte are vulnerable to increasing temperature than others; the commercial separator membranes possess low thermal stability (<130 °C), exposing the battery to the risk of internal short circuit and the organic electrolyte that is mixture of carbonate (e.g., ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl- or diethyl carbonate (DEC)) is highly flammable and volatile. Therefore, new material designs and strategies, especially the development of novel separator membrane and electrolyte, are necessary to reduce the risk of battery explosion caused by the thermal runaways inside the cell.

Cui and co-workers reported nonwoven electrospun core– sheath microfiber separator membrane that encapsulated a flame retardant of triphenyl phosphate (TPP) widely known as flame retardant materials based on organophosphorus inside a polymer sheath for LIBs (Figure 11a).[170] The sheath PVdF– HFP has many advantages of the use in LIB system owing to following reasons: i) low melting point (≈160 °C); ii) excellent electrochemical stability in the LIB system; and iii) insoluble in common electrolyte used in LIBs. Constructed graphite halfcell with the TPP@PVDF-HEP separator membrane showed stable long-term cyclability, which is similar to that of a commercial separator membrane, while significantly reduced the risk of typical thermal runaway process from the designed flame retardant at high temperature. As shown in Figure 11b,c, the polymer sheath (PVDF–HFP) of the separator membrane is melted by thermal stimuli (≈150 °C), and the encapsulated flame retardant (TPP) is simultaneously exposed to the electrolyte solution, thus preventing the battery ignition and explosion. As a result, not only is the TPP@PVDF–HFP separator membrane effective in suppressing the flammability of the organic electrolyte but also delivers the desired battery performances.
As mentioned previously, among the battery components, the current collector (Cu and Al currently used in the commercialized battery architecture) plays a significant role. In 2016, Bao and co-workers proposed reversible thermoresponsive polymer switching (TRPS) as a current collector for a safer LIB system (Figure 11d,e).[171] The TRPS was polymer composites containing the spiky shaped nanoparticles and low-density PE with the high coefficient of volumetric thermal expansion as a conductive filler and polymer matrix, respectively. The room temperature electrical conductivity of the TPRS polymer composite showed 50 S cm−1, which offers about two times higher than that of commonly reported conductive composite materials. Furthermore, the thermally induced switching of the TRPS polymer composite exhibited an ultrafast response to temperature changes (<1 s) and high reversibility (20 switching cycles). These results have proven to be not only effective in suppressing thermal runaway but also being suitable for energy storage systems. To further demonstrate the effect in thermal switching function of the TRPS polymer composite in the real battery system, LiCoO2 half-cell based on TRPS-film-coated current collectors was fabricated. As a result, the half-cell initially showed stable capacity retention at 25 °C but the capacity of the batteries showed almost zero capacity at high temperature (>70 °C), while the battery performances were almost fully recovered after cooling to room temperature. It indicates that thermal switching behavior of the batteries with TRPS-film-coated current collectors is a highly reversible and exhibits fast shutdown properties under abnormal temperature condition (Figure 11f).
Typically, additives are cost-effective and unique functional agents to enhance electrochemical properties such as cyclability as well as the physical property of electrolytes including ionic conduction in the energy storage devices.[23,36] In this feature article, we will only review state-of-the-art flame retardant additive based
on the thermally responsive polymer. For the flame retardant additives, their compatibility with other battery components, physicochemical stability, the electrochemical performance of the batteries should be considered. Kim and co-workers reported a novel thermal responsive microcapsule comprising a fireextinguishing material (1,1,1,2,2,3,4,5,5,5-decafluoro-3-methoxy4-(trifluoromethyl)pentane) with high retardant properties as an additive for achieving safety and high performance batteries (Figure 11g).[172] The microcapsule structure was designed in a form of core–shell of fire-retardant and crosslinked poly(methyl methacrylate), respectively. To validate the safety of the pouchshaped full batteries with the thermal responsive microcapsule additive, fully charged batteries with 500 mA h capacity were analyzed by the nail penetration testing. Surprisingly, the pouchshaped full cells based on fire-extinguishing microcapsules showed that the maximum cell temperature reached 37.2 °C (initial cell temperature is 25 °C) compared with that from conventional full battery architecture (72.3 °C) as shown in Figure 11h. The core–shell self-extinguishing microcapsule thus demonstrates a powerful strategy to realize a safe battery system without sacrificing the electrochemical performances even under severe abuse conditions.

sections.heading: 5.3. Nonflammable Electrolyte Designs
sections.text: A typical organic liquid electrolyte used in LIBs can extend to a high voltage, which accordingly increases the energy density of the batteries. However, serious safety concerns associated with the organic liquid electrolyte arise due to the use of solvent as a fire source as mentioned above in the introduction of Section 5. Thus, nonflammable materials, naturally inhibiting the thermal runaways, are strongly required such as a solid electrolyte (SE), high concentration solvent, and an aqueous electrolyte.

sections.heading: 5.3.1. Nonflammable Electrolyte
sections.text:
In recent years, organic electrolytes having inherently nonflammable (e.g., high concentration) characteristics have been proposed to ensure safe and high energy density cells.[173] Recently, Yamada’s group designed salt-concentrated electrolyte to improve safety and battery performance (Figure 12a,b).[174] The fire-extinguishing concentrated electrolytes consisting of the NaN(SO2F)2 (NaFSA) or LiN(SO2F)2 (LiFSA) dissolved in flame retardant trimethyl phosphate (TMP) solvent showed highly stable battery performance in terms of following aspects: i) the proposed salts (NaFSA and LiFSA) can make stable passivation SEI layer on the surface of the anode materials (Figure 12c); ii) improved interaction between the cations and solvent molecules leads to reduction of the congenital volatility of the solvent; and iii) when the triggering temperature increased, TMP solvent exhibits fire-extinguishing function. Full batteries based on the concentrated electrolyte (sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) and LIBs are used in NaFSA/ TMP and LiFSA/TMP, respectively) showed outstanding cycling performance (Figure 12d,e). Very recently, Zeng et al. reported state-of-the-art nonflammable phosphate electrolyte based on a concentrated electrolyte (lithium bis(trifluoromethane sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI)-tetraethyl phosphate(TEP)).[175] Compared with

As a result, the batteries showed a reversible capacity of 1982 mA h corresponding to an exceptional Coulombic efficiency of 99.7% and showed outstanding cyclic performance with 90% capacity retention over 50 charge/discharge cycles at 0.05 C.
