Apart from the novel design of organic solvent-based electrolytes, aqueous electrolytes based on water-based chemistry have recently received extensive attention owing to their inherent outstanding ionic conductivity, low cost, environmentally friendly and improved safety.[176] However, the aqueous rechargeable Li-ion batteries (ARLBs) possess a narrow operating voltage range (≈1.23 V). [15b] In 2015, Xu and co-workers made a breakthrough in the design of aqueous electrolyte (referred to as “water-in-salt,” WIS) that can significantly widen open-circuit voltage of around 2.3 V as shown in Figure 12f.[177] The WIS aqueous electrolyte consisted of a highly concentrated solution (>20 m) of LiTFSI. The ARLB full batteries based on the WIS electrolyte, where LiMnO2 and Mo6S8 were cathode and anode, respectively, showed superior cycle life with a capacity retention of 68% at a rate of 0.15 C
after 1000 cycles. These results profoundly impacted battery society which holds a great possibility of introducing the aqueous battery system to EV and ESS applications required fast charging properties, high energy density, and safety properties, while the high cost of LiTFSI salts and high weight of concentrated electrolytes lie in the way of practical applications.

sections.heading: 5.3.2. Solid-State Electrolyte
sections.text:
The development of nonflammable liquid electrolytes aims at completely solving battery safety concerns.[178] However, liquid-based batteries still have challenges to overcome such as leakage, internal shorts, and so on. In this regard, solid-state electrolyte is one of the most promising candidates to address the above issues (Figure 13a).[179] Furthermore, the SE provides
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1902499
1902499 (25 of 30) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
the ability to apply alkali metal anodes without any concerns on dendrite formation, which allows us to achieve advanced battery systems with high energy density for EV and grid-scale energy systems. In general, the SE such as oxide (e.g., LiPON, garnets, and LISICON), sulfide materials (e.g., Li10GeP2S12 and Li9.54Si1.74P1.44S11.7Cl0.3), and polymer (e.g., poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO)) have been reported (Figure 13b). Although the use of the inorganic SE guarantees safe battery performance, various obstacles including naturally poor ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability, and the large impedance at the SE-active material interface have plagued practical applications of LIBs. The polymer electrolytes have several advantages including low interfacial resistance, cost-effective manufacturing process, high flexibility, but possess intrinsically low ionic transport ability (10−6 S cm−1 at room temperature).
Current oxide-based SE features high stability at ambient conditions but shows lower a room temperature ionic conductivity of 10−2 ≈ 10−4 S cm−1. In comparison, sulfide-based SE not only exhibits high mobility of Li-ion (1.2 × 10−2 S cm−1) but also enables low-temperature sintering process. However, their poor chemical stability in the air hinders further progress of all-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) with sulfide SE due to its moisture sensitivity. Additionally, both oxide and sulfide-SEs are not able to address the interfacial contact issue between the active materials and SE, which eventually failed to achieve long-term stability of the battery. Recently, Jung’s group investigated the electrochemical and mechanical properties of a LiCoO2 composite cathode with sulfide glass 4LiI-0.6Li3SnS4 superionic conductor fabricated via a scalable and homogenous solution process.[180] This solution coating process facilitates the intimate contact at the interfaces between the SE and active materials, resulting in practical device-level performance. Furthermore, the excellent cycling performance of sulfide glass coated cathode upon exposure to dry air renders ASSB more promising toward future technology. Similar to LIBs, NIBs also suffer from safety concerns originated from the use of liquid organic electrolytes. Very recently, Nazar’s group proposed a new sodium conductor (Na11Sn2PS12) with marvelous Li+ mobility (1.4 mS cm−1) for ASSBs.[181] The superior conductor has a unique single crystal structure with ordered Sn/P tetrahedra that provides an efficient Na-ion transport pathway determined by crystal X-ray diffraction, as further corroborated by theoretical calculation methods such as density functional theory (DFT) and ab initio molecular dynamics to understand the Na-ion diffusion behavior in Na11Sn2PS12. This result showed that the 3D diffusion pathways in the crystal structure were synchronized with the crystal X-ray diffraction, which described the high ionic conductivity of Na11Sn2PS12.
Alkali metal anodes such as lithium and sodium have drawn extensive interest for their potential high energy density.[182] Nevertheless, the practical use in battery systems, however, has been hindered due to detrimental dendrite growth. Although an efficacious approach to circumvent the dendrite issue was mentioned in Section 2.1, the SE has been also considered to be an attractive strategy due to its enough mechanical moduli to suppress the metal dendrite growth during repeated electrochemical cycling.[183] Very recently, multitalented polymer electrolytes composed of Mg2B2O5 nanowires and PEO as an ionic conductor and polymer matrix, respectively, were prepared by
Sheng et al. (Figure 13c,d).[184] The polymer electrolyte with Mg2B2O5 nanowires showed high ionic conductivity associated with the improved the PEO polymer segmental movement and further increased Li+ mobility on the interface between PEOLiTFSI and Mg2B2O5, resulting in the good electrochemical performance (Figure 13e). Moreover, the PEO-LiTFSI-Mg2B2O5 polymer electrolyte showed an improved flame-resistant property compared with the organic liquid electrolyte and PEOLiTFSI electrolyte, indicating that the Mg2B2O5 supplements poor stability of the polymer electrolyte as shown in Figure 13f. Although the polymer solid electrolytes are a promising candidate for realizing metal anode batteries with high safety, their low ionic conduction still remains a challenge to be solved.

sections.heading: 5.4. Modification of Cathode Materials
sections.text: In the LIB system, various lithium transition metal oxides have been widely used as cathode materials. As mentioned in Section 5.1, when the temperature increased to above 180 °C and charged to high voltages (>4.7), the cathode undergoes a phase transition and molecular oxygen release, which pose degradation of battery performance as well as a safety concern. Several approaches, especially concentration gradient structure and surface coating technique, to improve the thermal stability of the cathode materials under the thermal abuse conditions has been proposed.[185] Lim et al reported a novel concentration gradient cathode (Li[Ni0.65Co0.13Mn0.22]O2) synthesized by the home-made reactor. The cathode materials have been devised to optimize the condition of the Ni and Mn element inside of particles.[186] The full batteries based on the fully gradient cathode exhibited outstanding capacity retention of around 88% over 1500 cycles. Another approach to design thermally stable cathode materials is a coating method of various materials with high Li+ transport ability and electrochemical stability.[187] Sun et al. proposed AlF3 coated Li-rich layered oxide cathode, resulting in improved thermal stability and battery performance.[188] Very recently, Mu et al. studied a mechanism of chemical and mechanical breakdown in the Li1−xNi0.4Mn0.4Co0.2O2 cathode material under hightemperature conditions.[189] These phenomena were directly observed by using in situ environmental transmission electron microscopy (ETEM) and finite element simulations (FEM). In this result, thermal abuse condition boosted oxygen activity and release and induced structural transformation of cathode materials, which led to eventually not only severe battery performance but also a safety concern. This finding based on state-ofthe-art measurement offered insight into new design strategies for advanced cathode materials with safety feature and high electrochemical performance.

sections.heading: 6. Concluding Remarks
sections.text:
In summary, rechargeable battery systems, Li-based chemistries (especially, LIBs and Li–S), are one of the most important landmark technologies in human history and have profoundly reshaped our lifestyle over the past two decades with their use in portable consumer electronic gadgets. However, the Li-based batteries remain with challenges in terms of battery

performance and safety for use in future applications including deformable electronic devices, EVs, and grid-scale storage system. In this feature article, we covered a comprehensive but concise review on recent progress on the design of state-of-theart nano/micro material and pioneering achievements to drive the “smart rechargeable batteries.”
Currently, Li–S batteries have been extensively studied but have two formidable obstacles for commercialization such as dissolving sulfur cathode and uncontrollable pure Li metal during cycles. First, to overcome dissolution of the sulfur cathode during cycles, interfacial functional materials, which call for kinetic accelerators classified by operating positions such as cathode interface and electrolyte regulators, expedite both charge transfer and ion transport. Approaches to suppressing the dendritic formation of lithium metal anode include artificial cage matrixes as well as controls of charge transport and Li reactivity at the interface. Despite the significant improvements of Li–S batteries through multiple strategies described above, the insufficient cycle life of batteries at high sulfur loading, low N/P ratio, and low E/C (ratio of electrolyte amounts to cathode capacity) conditions is a daunting challenge.
A self-healing feature at nano/micro scale, of which ability to self-repair when damaged, is predominantly desirable for continuously changing rechargeable battery system during electrochemical reactions. Thus, flexible and stretchable electronic devices necessitate the self-healing property that is highly exposed to damages from repeated physical deformations; for example, under mechanical repeated damages, all self-healable devices preserve their electrical and function. While self-healing properties are valuable, the following requirements need to be overcome to make self-healing properties feasible: i) the short time required to repair the damaged or deformed materials and ii) retention of material properties and device function during repetitive self-healing process.
The functional separator membranes fundamentally serve as the electrolyte reservoir to enable ionic pathway while preventing physical contact of both electrodes. In rechargeable batteries, a variety of impurities from various sources such as Mn-based cathode materials and sulfur cathode deteriorate electrochemical performance. Mn-based materials are a suitable candidate for EV applications due to their favorable electrochemical feature and economical effect. However, Mn-ion dissolved out from LMO cathode in LIB systems provokes detrimental side reactions on the anode surface, resulting in the rapid capacity fading further accelerated at elevated temperature because generated HF attacks the Mn-cathode. Among various strategies to suppress Mn dissolution, functional separator membrane with scavenging HF and chelating Mn ion effectively improve cycling stability even under high temperature condition, which call for an in-depth basic study on the understanding of transition metal ion dissolution and HF generation by using advanced in situ and operando monitoring, while ion selectivity of separator membranes effectively inhibited shuttle phenomenon of polysulfides. Also, lightweight separator membrane with the above functionality is required to achieve high volumetric and specific energy density batteries.
With increased battery performances based on organic electrolytes in terms of energy density and fast charging ability, safety concerns of such systems become much crucial. Among
battery components, polymer separator and organic liquid electrolyte have lower thermal stability, which leads to thermal runaway processes under abuse conditions. In this review, a simple and an efficient strategy including thermal response polymer and nonflammable electrolyte (e.g., SE and aqueous electrolyte) is described to overcome the safety concern of triggered thermal runaway processes without the sacrifice of battery performance. Further deep insights into in situ experimental and theoretical simulations are expected to help completely understand thermal runaway processes, consisting of extremely complicated chain reactions. Additionally, cooperation between academia society and battery industry will produce a safer battery system to prevent a recurrence of battery explosion at consumer’s hands. It is believed that the nano/micro functional materials introduced in this review revolutionize our lifestyle by implementing “smart rechargeable batteries” with high specific and volumetric energy density, and unique and beneficial features.

metadata.abstractText: The imperative to electrify the transport sector in the past few decades has put millions of electric vehicles on the road worldwide with an extended mile range from critical technological breakthroughs in developing the rechargeable energy storage systems, which also covers electronic devices and smart grid applications. However, the available energy density of prevailing systems in the market (i.e., batteries) is reaching its boundaries due to the limited choice of electrochemical reactions that necessarily depend on the thermodynamics and kinetics of the components (e.g., cathode, anode, electrolyte, separator, and current collectors). Reaching the high energy density of batteries exploits new redox chemistry such as sensitive metal anodes, insulating and highly dissolving sulfur cathodes, etc., thus requiring novel designs of various multiscale functional materials to address the corresponding issues. Here, the recent achievements on the designs of smart functional materials for emerging problems in the whole range of systems are discussed: i) interfacial control/kinetic regulation of Li–S battery; ii) self-healing-driven structural stability in the electrode and electrolyte; iii) ion-sieving functional membranes for selective scavenging capability; and iv) functional materials to ensure battery safety.
